p: During the nineteenth century, dengue was considered a disease that sporadically caused epidemics at long intervals, a reflection of the slow pace of transport and limited travel at that time. Dengue has emerged as a worldwide problem since the 1950s, and in the last 50 years, the incidence has increased 30-fold. Although dengue is rarely found in the continental United States, it is endemic in Puerto Rico and in many popular tourist destinations in Latin America, Southeast Asia and the Pacific islands (Fig. 2.14).
